Welcome To The Hop
Yesterday, about 580 young people attended their first
class at Johns Hopkins. The academic challenge at this
University presents something new and different for every
freshman; yet, it is not the most valuable part of being a
student here. Everyone has had classes before, in prep or
high school and before that in grammar school. Many will
go on to still more classes in other institutions after leaving
Hopkins. Through an academic program here, a person can
learn a great deal, grow intellectually, and prepare for a
career later in life. But by themselves, classes are not the
richest part of being a student at Johns Hopkins.
The total life experience available to an undergraduate
enrolled at this University is of tremendous value. It is a
fairy-tale method for passing from the adolescent to the
adult world. A student can arrange his life any way he
chooses; yet he is still protected in some ways by a guardian
angel, the University. People who circulate about
Homewood are nothing if not diverse; birds of all kinds find
themselves Blue Jays. You might come across an expert
chess player or scuba diver, or somebody who has been to
Togo and back. You will definitely come across somebody
who can wiggle a webbed stick. The male-female student
ratio is lamentable, but still the social scene at Hopkins
offers great potential for stimulation.
Regrettably, a considerable number of undergraduates at
this University consider their present occupation as simply a
means to an end. No matter how successfully they may
pursue their goals, they waste their time here. The JHU
experience can and should be fulfilling in itself...
So relax and enjoy your stay at Johns Hopkins--it's a part
of your life that you will only have once.

Good Luck, GRO
Graduate students form an unusually large and active
part of the Hopkins community. Thus, the recent move to
establish an organization to represent them here comes as a
welcome break I from the customary philosophy of
independent dealings within each department. The potential
for unity among grads in all fields stands out as a promising
feature of the proposed group.
An effective organization could obtain tangible benefits
for its constituents. Financial dealings between the
academic departments and their graduate students, like too
much of what occurs in faculty circles, have
traditionally been shrouded in secrecy. This situation is
against the interests of most grads, since they have .no real
way of knowing how much stipend students have received
in the vast and in other departments. An active G.R.O.
could notionly articulate graduate student needs; it could
also provide a mechanism for the long and persistent
investigations needed to pierce the shroud. But with this as
with any project the proof of the pudding is in the eating.
We can only say good luck, and wait to see what the new
group can do.

GRAD STUDENTS, UNITE!
Two years ago Johns Hopkins
University celebrated the 100th
anniversary of its foundation as
the first graduate school in
America. Throughout 1975-6 the
University administration
emphasized repeatedly the
achievements of graduate
education. Ironically, the only
organized body of students to
play a role in those celebrations
was an organization representing
undergraduates—the Student
Council.
Graduate students, who are
being trained for future roles as
leaders for the intellectual
community, take no part in the
decisions that shape their lives
here and now in the Hopkins
community. There exists no
university-wide organization
which can give a voice to
graduate students' interests.
Graduate students are parochially
divided into their departments,
and even inside the majority of
those have no forum through
which to express their opinions
or needs.
Yet graduate students share
many common interests
concerning the most basic issues.
All graduate students need a
minimum level of support that
will allow them to teach and do
research. Stipends and salaries are
allocated to departments by
policy determined entirely
behind closed doors. The support
given the average student, as well
as the availability of low-cost
loans and other financial aid, has
declined sharply over the last ten
years. Most graduate students,
even those who teach, are
supported at a level far below
that of other universities, and
below what they can possibly live
on. At the same time, the ratio of
graduates to undergraduates has
changed from roughly l -to-1 to
1 -to-2, so that demands on
graduate students to serve as
teachers have increased. Not only

do graduate students suffer, but
undergraduates do as well, for
they cannot expect the quality of
their instruction to improve
when those who are asked to do
a major part of the teaching lack
sufficient time because they must
also take outside jobs.
Money is by no means the
only issue which affects all
graduate students. University
housing, and outside housing, are
in increasingly short supply while
rents rise sharply. Health
insurance costs have spiraled.
Library conditions have
worsened while suitable study
and office space is virtually
unavailable. Access to books and
other working tools is often
difficult. Women students
encounter obstacles in many
areas of university life. Most
important, graduate students are
not represented on either
departmental or university levels
in the decisions on all these issues
that shape their personal and
professional lives.
Not all graduate students are
affected equally by all of these
questions. Others may have other
concerns. But all graduate
students will continue to be

The mini Woody Allen film festival continues with the

among the best of any American filmmaker's today.
Sleeper is about life 200 years in the future. Allen, a
20th-century Rip van Winkle, wakes in this new era and
encounters everything from robot butlers to crazed
revolutionaries still trying to overthrow the government.
Annie Hall is a "nervous romance," somewhat

especially Diane Keaton, who won Best Actress for her

The comic technique in his earlier films was rather
corny, and occasionally stupid. The plot was good, but
often seemed dictated by his attempt to make a joke.
These jokes were puns and one-liners that came after a
series of developments that led to the punch line. Allen
.was a stand-upcomedian before turning to film, and Play
It Again Sam and Take the Money and Run often seem
like a stand-up routine on film with a plot weaving in and
out of the humor.

sophisticated. The comedy in Sleeper is physical, and in
Love and Death which followed, it is verbal. But on the
periphery of these comedies, there is a feeling of drama

becomes as important as the story. Thus it is a very

Yesterday, about 580 young people attended their first
class at Johns Hopkins. The academic challenge at this
University presents something new and different for every
freshman; yet, it is not the most valuable part of being a
student here. Everyone has had classes before, in prep or
high school and before that in grammar school. Many will
go on to still more classes in other institutions after leaving
Hopkins. Through an academic program here, a person can
learn a great deal, grow intellectually, and prepare for a
career later in life. But by themselves, classes are not the
richest part of being a student at Johns Hopkins.
The total life experience available to an undergraduate
enrolled at this University is of tremendous value. It is a
fairy-tale method for passing from the adolescent to the
adult world. A student can arrange his life any way he
chooses; yet he is still protected in some ways by a guardian
angel, the University. People who circulate about
Homewood are nothing if not diverse; birds of all kinds find

chess player or scuba diver, or somebody who has been to
Togo and back. You will definitely come across somebody
who can wiggle a webbed stick. The male-female student
ratio is lamentable, but still the social scene at Hopkins
offers great potential for stimulation.

this University consider their present occupation as simply a
means to an end. No matter how successfully they may
pursue their goals, they waste their time here. The JHU
experience can and should be fulfilling in itself...
So relax and enjoy your stay at Johns Hopkins--it's a part
of your life that you will only have once.

GRAD STUDENTS, UNITE!
Two years ago Johns Hopkins
University celebrated the 100th
anniversary of its foundation as
the first graduate school in
America. Throughout 1975-6 the
University administration
emphasized repeatedly the
achievements of graduate
education. Ironically, the only
organized body of students to
play a role in those celebrations
was an organization representing
undergraduates—the Student
Council.
Graduate students, who are
being trained for future roles as
leaders for the intellectual
community, take no part in the
decisions that shape their lives
here and now in the Hopkins
community. There exists no
university-wide organization
which can give a voice to
graduate students' interests.
Graduate students are parochially
divided into their departments,
and even inside the majority of
those have no forum through
which to express their opinions
or needs.
Yet graduate students share
many common interests
concerning the most basic issues.
All graduate students need a
minimum level of support that
will allow them to teach and do
research. Stipends and salaries are
allocated to departments by
policy determined entirely
behind closed doors. The support
given the average student, as well
as the availability of low-cost
loans and other financial aid, has
declined sharply over the last ten
years. Most graduate students,
even those who teach, are
supported at a level far below
that of other universities, and
below what they can possibly live
on. At the same time, the ratio of
graduates to undergraduates has
changed from roughly l -to-1 to
1 -to-2, so that demands on
graduate students to serve as
teachers have increased. Not only

do graduate students suffer, but
undergraduates do as well, for
they cannot expect the quality of
their instruction to improve
when those who are asked to do
a major part of the teaching lack
sufficient time because they must
also take outside jobs.
Money is by no means the
only issue which affects all
graduate students. University
housing, and outside housing, are
in increasingly short supply while
rents rise sharply. Health
insurance costs have spiraled.
Library conditions have
worsened while suitable study
and office space is virtually
unavailable. Access to books and
other working tools is often
difficult. Women students
encounter obstacles in many
areas of university life. Most
important, graduate students are
not represented on either
departmental or university levels
in the decisions on all these issues
that shape their personal and
professional lives.
Not all graduate students are
affected equally by all of these
questions. Others may have other
concerns. But all graduate
students will continue to be
ignored in the decision-making
processes long as they have no
means to make their views
known to the University.
Whatever their concerns, they
will remain unvoiced; they will
not even be informed when
decisions vital to their welfare are
to be made.
To remedy this situation,
graduate students began to work
together last spring to form a
university -wide organization.
More than 200 graduate students
attended meetings or expressed
interest. A provisional council of
representatives was formed,
representing 24 of the 26
departments at Homewood, and
has continued to work hard since
that time. It has approved a draft
of a constitution for a Graduate

(7

Representative Organization
which will be presented for
discussion at a mass meeting
Wednesday, September 13 at
5:00 in the Listening-Viewing
Room.
The provisional council has
negotiated with the University to
obtain representatives
on University committees and a
budget for a graduate student
organization. It also organized
the first University orientation
program for new graduate
students and will hold a free
picnic in Gilman quad this
Saturday afternoon for graduate
students from all departments.
At the same time, committees on
numerous issues have continued
to work, collecting information
and examining University
policies.
We believe all of these
activities are vital to all graduate
students at Johns Hopkins. None
of our projects can be completed,
nor our hopes brought to
fruition, without the active
participation of large numbers of
graduate students from all
departments. But by joining
together to establish a Graduate
Representative Organization,
graduate students can begin to
play the role that is their right in
decisions affecting their lives.
Through a Graduate
Representative Organization we
can express and defend our
interests, as well as develop a
community that extends beyond
department boundaries. We urge
all graduate students to takepart
in forming that community by
coming to Saturday's picnic, and
we urge you to help found the
Graduate Representative
Organization in your
departments and at next
Wednesday's open meeting.

MOVIES: The Baltimore metropolitan area has nearly
100 movie houses and 20 drive-ins. Those closest to
Hopkins are the Rotunda Cinemas, which feature major
first-run films, and the Playhouse, one of the few theatres
in town that shows the best of foreign films like
Amarcord and Cat and Mouse. A short bus ride up
Greenmount Avenue brings you to another fine movie
house, the Senator. In addition, the Enoch Pratt Library
has weekly series of free films. For details, call the Pratt

Theatr4 both downtown. This season at Center Stage
consists of Shadow Box, Born Yesterday, A Christmas

enhibits of the late 19th- and early 20th-Century art. This
exhibit, the ConeCollection, contains a dazzling selection
of paintings by Henri Matisse. The Walters Art Gallery on
Cathedral Street is likewise a must for art fans. Other
museums of interest include the Peale, which specializes
in artifacts of Baltimore history, the Baltimore and Ohio
Transportation Museum, the Maryland Science Center, at
the Inner Harbor, and the Lovely Lane Museum. The
latter is part of the Lovely Lane Church on St. Paul
Street, itself a work of art; the church is the only building
in Baltimore designed by the famous architect Stanford
White.

BY ROS RESNICK
Arsenic and Old Lace, Hopkins' premiere student
production, opened the season with zany humor and
delightful death. Although parts of the play were out,of
synch, its excellent acting and irony made the production
very enjoyable.
Joseph Kesselreig's play, produced here by Writing
Seminars professor Robert Arellano, concerns the
eccentric Brewster family, whose members demonstrate
their individuality in deadly ways. Two spinster sisters,
Abby and Martha, take pity on twelve elderly
"gentlemen" by lulling them to the Big Sleep with
elderberry wine. Their nephew, who thinks he's Teddy
Roosevelt, joyfully buries what he thinks are malaria
victim; in the locks of the Panama Canal. Later on in the
play, another nephew turns out to be a wanted murderer
and competes with his aunts in the "most victims"
contest.
Chris Stutz (Abby) steals the show with her matronly
delicacy and gossipy giggle. One of the play's funniest
scenes occurs when Abby and Martha shamelessly tell
their only normal nephew about their little secret. Joanna
Shwartz (Martha), who replaced Celeste Yousoof in the
Thursday production, deserves much credit for her quick
memorization and ease in playing second fiddle to Chris.
Rick Vaum (Jonathan) must be the most sinister presence
to hit the stage since Boris Karloff. Robert Anthenelli
(Mortimer) succeeds as the fidgety, but not homicidal,
nephew and drama critic.
Set in Brooklyn, Arsenic and Old Lace demands long
hours of practicing accents. Ruth Bosch (Officer O'Hara)
charms with her flawless Irish brogue and Basil Zaharias
(Officer Klein) does a Brooklyn accent that even the
Lords of Flatbush would consider cool. Mark Wolkow
(Mr. Gibbs) is also full of other witty tidbits such as the
continual stream of jibes against play reviewers. As the
ultimate insult, Mortimer's girlfriend yells after him,
"You critic!"
